THE OIL JOLT

The rise in oil prices on world markets slowed, and the reported Saudi pledge to produce an additional two million barrels a day, combined with production increases expected from other nations, may stem further price rises, analysts said. [Page D1.]

For corporate America and the U.S. economy, the sudden rise in oil prices could not have come at a worse time. With the economy already weak, the added drag of sharply higher energy costs is likely to slash corporate profits, economists say. [D1.]

Natural gas is getting new consideration. Huge volumes of natural gas, long regarded by oil producers as the crab grass of fossil fuels, have been left in the ground because of the expense of bringing it to market. That may change. [D1.]
Oil companies are preparing to redeploy tanker fleets to pick up oil from alternative producers, and they are already paying a price for Mideast instability in higher insurance rates. [D5.]
MARKETS
The stock market continued to react nervously, but after a steep three-day slide the Dow lost just 5.70, to 2,710.64. [D1.]
The Japanese stock market recovered some of yesterday's losses and the world's other major stock markets rose or declined only slightly. [D4.]
Credit markets were buffeted by conflicting reports about the Mideast crisis, causing prices of Treasury securities to continue dropping until a late rally cut the losses by half. [D14.]
The dollar ended higher against all major currencies except the German mark. Gold prices were mixed. [D15.] Cattle futures prices surged, but pork, grains and soybean futures were mixed. [D15.]
THE ECONOMY
It will take the Government two to three years to secure indictments against most of those suspected of savings and loan fraud and five years to clean up most of the cases, Thornburgh said. [D2.]
The Federal Reserve said consumers repaid car loans much faster than they took out new ones in June. [D2.]
COMPANIES
The publisher of Psychology Today and Mother Earth News sold a 50 percent stake in his New American Magazine Company to a Japanese publishing company. [D18.]
Sir Geoffrey Owen will step down as Financial Times editor at the end of this year. [D18.]
In a victory for large franchise operations, a judge has ruled that franchisers can negotiate deals that vary from their offering documents. The ruling came in a lawsuit filed by Southland. [D3.]
INTERNATIONAL
The Soviet Union said it would open money exchanges to allow businesses to trade rubles freely for foreign currencies. [D1.]
BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY
Techniques are being perfected to cut sharply the cost of making composite materials - strong, light combinations of complementary substances. [D7.]
A system using infrared cameras to improve drivers' perception of the road in poor visibility is being worked on by BMW. [D7.]
TODAY'S COLUMNS
The powerful Japanese economy appears strong enough to ride out the storm of higher oil prices and disrupted supplies. Economic Scene. [D2.]
The best strategy for individual investors to take in the wake of the Middle Eastern crisis might well be to sit tight, many Wall Street executives say. Market Place. [D8.]
The outdoor advertising industry, which has been battered by special-interest groups and Federal lawmakers, faces continued tough times Kim Foltz: Advertising. [D18.]
